result.markdown:
--- title: "Ant Morphology Analysis" description: "Statistical analysis on the morphology and resource preference in ants" author: "Gabriel Guzman" date: "2023-03-23" categories: [Data Analytics, Biology] image: "aphaenogaster_gibbosa.JPG" format: html: code-overflow: wrap link-external-icon: true link-external-newwindow: true --- # Altitude Associated Changes in ant Morphology and Genus-dependent Resource Preference in Guadarrama Ants ::: columns ::: {.column width="43%"} This analysis is based on a several studies taking place in the Guadarra Mountains of Spain by the same group of scientists. Scientists measured the size of the different morphological structures of a multitude of ant genera across varying altitudes and regions of Guadarra mountain range as well as the resources ants were observed using. We aim to analyze how the size of the measured morphological features varies with altitude as well as to understand a genus-specific preference for certain resource types across ant taxa. The data sets we used can be found here:
  • [Ant_traits_in_central_Spain](https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.14596065.v1){.external target="_blank"}
  • [AntsInGuadarrama](https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.13246619.v1){.external target="_blank"}
The original research papers can be found here:
  • [Diverging facets of grassland ant diversity along a Mediterranean elevational gradient](hhttps://doi.org/10.1111/een.13077){.external target="_blank"}
  • Author(s): Mariola Silvestre, Carlos Carmona, Francisco Azcárate, Javier Seoane.
  • [Abiotic controls, but not species richness, shape niche overlap and breadth of ant assemblages along an elevational gradient in central Spain](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.actao.2020.103695){.external target="_blank"}
  • Author(s): Javier Seoane, Mariola Silvestre, Violeta Hevia, Rubén Ariño and Francisco Azcárate.
::: ::: {.column width="4%"} ::: ::: {.column width="53%"} ![](aphaenogaster_gibbosa.JPG "Title: Aphaenogaster gibossa"){fig-alt="Aphaenogaster gibossa" fig-align="center"} ::: ::: :::{screen-inset-shaded} ![](aphaenogaster_gibbosa.JPG "Title: Aphaenogaster gibossa"){fig-alt="Aphaenogaster gibossa" fig-align="center"} ::: -------- ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Install and Load Packages #Downloading all desired packages into local device install.packages ("tidyverse", repos = "https://cran.rstudio.com") #This package allows for simplified and more intuitive syntax in R install.packages ("rstatix", repos = "https://cran.rstudio.com") #This package allows for a variety of tests for statistical significance with the use of its integrated functions install.packages ("ggplot2", repos = "https://cran.rstudio.com") #This package allows for the #Loading all libraries into current R notebook library (tidyverse) library (rstatix) library (ggplot2) ``` ::: ## HYPOTHESIS 1 ### Data Summary Calculations ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Import Data + Create Dataframes Ant = read.csv("Ant_traits_in_central_Spain.csv", header = TRUE) #Importing data set into R from local device for Hypothesis 1 head_mean = mean(Ant$head) #Create data frame for the mean size of ant head print(head_mean) #Output the value in 'head_mean', the mean size of the head leg_mean = mean(Ant$leg) #Create data frame for the mean size of ant leg print(leg_mean) #Output the value in 'leg_mean', the mean size of the leg scape_mean = mean(Ant$scape) #Create data frame for the mean size of ant scape print(scape_mean) #Output the value in 'scape_mean', the mean size of the scape eye_mean = mean(Ant$scape) #Create data frame for the mean size of ant eye print(eye_mean) #Output the value in 'eye_mean', the mean size of the eye ``` ::: ### Test for Statistical Significance (Linear Regression) ::: columns ::: {.column width="48%"} Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Pellentesque habitant morbi tristique senectus et netus et malesuada fames ac turpis egestas. ::: ::: {.column width="4%"} ::: ::: {.column width="48%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mod_eye = lm(eye ~ altitude, data = Ant) #Creation of a linear model calculations for head measurements in relation to altitude summary(mod_eye) #Displaying the results of the linear model calculation ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Call: lm(formula = eye ~ altitude, data = Ant) Residuals: Min 1Q Median 3Q Max -0.18512 -0.07062 -0.01803 0.06336 0.40555 Coefficients: Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) (Intercept) 2.343e-01 8.131e-03 28.814 < 2e-16 *** altitude -2.227e-05 5.992e-06 -3.716 0.000213 *** --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 Residual standard error: 0.09223 on 1064 degrees of freedom (13 observations deleted due to missingness) Multiple R-squared: 0.01281, Adjusted R-squared: 0.01189 F-statistic: 13.81 on 1 and 1064 DF, p-value: 0.0002126 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: ::: columns ::: {.column width="48%"} Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Error t value Pr(>|t|) (Intercept) 1.187e+00 3.613e-02 32.863 < 2e-16 *** altitude -1.252e-04 2.663e-05 -4.701 2.92e-06 *** --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 Residual standard error: 0.4098 on 1064 degrees of freedom (13 observations deleted due to missingness) Multiple R-squared: 0.02035, Adjusted R-squared: 0.01943 F-statistic: 22.1 on 1 and 1064 DF, p-value: 2.925e-06 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: ::: columns ::: {.column width="48%"} Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Error t value Pr(>|t|) (Intercept) 1.486e+00 5.796e-02 25.646 < 2e-16 *** altitude -2.368e-04 4.271e-05 -5.543 3.74e-08 *** --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 Residual standard error: 0.6574 on 1064 degrees of freedom (13 observations deleted due to missingness) Multiple R-squared: 0.02807, Adjusted R-squared: 0.02716 F-statistic: 30.73 on 1 and 1064 DF, p-value: 3.743e-08 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: ::: columns ::: {.column width="48%"} Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Error t value Pr(>|t|) (Intercept) 1.324e+00 4.402e-02 30.087 < 2e-16 *** altitude -2.205e-04 3.244e-05 -6.796 1.78e-11 *** --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 Residual standard error: 0.4993 on 1064 degrees of freedom (13 observations deleted due to missingness) Multiple R-squared: 0.04161, Adjusted R-squared: 0.04071 F-statistic: 46.19 on 1 and 1064 DF, p-value: 1.783e-11 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: Result: All morphological features analyzed had a statistically significant relation to altitude (p-value < 0.05) ### Figure Creation (Linear Regression) ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Linear regression figure for eye size ggplot(Ant,aes(x=altitude, y=eye)) + geom_point() + theme_classic() + #Change theme for aesthetics geom_smooth(method="lm") + labs(x='Altitude (in meters)', y='Logged Eye Size') ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-11-1.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # Linear regression figure for head size ggplot(Ant,aes(x=altitude, y=head)) + geom_point() + theme_classic() + geom_smooth(method="lm") + labs(x='Altitude (in meters)', y='Logged Head Size') ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-11-2.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # Linear regression figure for leg size ggplot(Ant,aes(x=altitude, y=leg)) + geom_point() + theme_classic() + geom_smooth(method="lm") + labs(x='Altitude (in meters)', y='Logged Leg Size') ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-11-3.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # Linear regression figure for scape size ggplot(Ant,aes(x=altitude, y=scape)) + geom_point() + theme_classic() + geom_smooth(method="lm") + labs(x='Altitude (in meters)', y='Logged Scape Size') ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-11-4.png){width=672} ::: ::: Result: Four figures depicting the relationship of ant morphology to altitude # TL;DR ::: columns ::: {.column width="48%"} This analysis is based on a several studies taking place in the Guadarra Mountains of Spain by the same group of scientists. Scientists measured the size of the different morphological structures of a multitude of ant genera across varying altitudes and regions of Guadarra mountain range as well as the resources ants were observed using. We aim to analyze how the size of the measured morphological features varies with altitude as well as to understand a genus-specific preference for certain resource types across ant taxa. ::: ::: {.column width="4%"} ::: ::: {.column width="48%"} ![](aphaenogaster_gibbosa.JPG "Title: Aphaenogaster gibossa"){fig-alt="Aphaenogaster gibossa" fig-align="center"} ::: :::
